text: Oh, I'm a freelancer who does content updates, in case you decide to outsource it! How hands off it is depends on whether the client is working with me on strategy too and whether they've added me to their CRM. Sometimes I handle everything from identifying the URLs to update to publishing the (with approval steps between). Other times they've prepared a brief for the update and I work from that PDF into a Google Doc and that's it. Totally depends on what you need and your available resources.

text: Good morning - help needed! I'm kind of new to the world of QR codes etc... I'm looking to create a business card handout with a QR code on it - can anyone advise what the best way of doing this is - design the business card as normal, embed the QR code into the design and print like any other business card? In terms of the QR code, any recommendations for QR code generators that can track who is engaging? I'm looking for one that integrates with HubSpot preferably :slightly_smiling_face: My end goal is to create some sort of landing page with links to resources, videos, guides etc, that can be constantly updated - I guess this is best done like any normal landing page, but using UTM tracking in the URL? Help and advice needed - TIA xx

In terms of the QR code, any recommendations for QR code generators that can track who is engaging? I'm looking for one that integrates with HubSpot preferably

My end goal is to create some sort of landing page with links to resources, videos, guides etc, that can be constantly updated - I guess this is best done like any normal landing page, but using UTM tracking in the URL? Help and advice needed - TIA xx

text:
I feel that one of the more common problems marketing teams face internally is everyone else either “knowing marketing better” or asking themselves “so…what’s marketing doing anyway?!”

I’d answer those questions with the newsletter. I’d showcase monthly wins (and how the team got there, what was the thinking behind it, etc. — all without sounding like you’re making an excuse).

I’d also showcase any stories from customers or good reviews. People like these stories because they remind them everyone’s part of the story.

Oh, and I’d make it all a bit cheeky (provided company policy allows me) and definitely funny. Nobody wants to open a corporate newsletter where “we’re proudly announcing that…” every month.

+ absolutely what everyone else here said.

Oh, and I’d make it all a bit cheeky (provided company policy allows me) and definitely funny. Nobody wants to open a corporate newsletter where “we’re proudly announcing that…” every month.

text: I would think UTM tracking would do it. A quick and dirty fix which I used for an event last year was use <http://bit.ly|bit.ly> as the URL for the QR code which then directed to website, and so I tracked click numbers in bitly.

text:
Hey all, we run a series of Q&A articles with industry figures on our website. Current practice is to use H2 for the questions and body text for the answers. Have a sneaking suspicion this might not be the best practice. Any thoughts?
(Let me know if wrong channel, did a quick search in case Q already asked and saw lots of refs to H2 tags etc. in this chat)

text: Most people searching for that kind of content are likely to be inexperienced, so start off with some entry level topics, well explained. As to your concern about people taking your advice and using it rather than reaching out to you - I've often searched for blogs like this to broaden my knowledge and know what I'm talking about, but don't have time to _fully_ learn all the concepts and so usually outsource. I'd guess (and only a guess) that you'd find there are plenty of leads who would be in the same boat.

thanks joel

text: I really don't have much context but Q&A topics will rank much better with an FAQ schema: <https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/structured-data/faqpage>

attachments.fallback: Google Developers: Mark Up FAQs with Structured Data | Google Search Central  |  Documentation  |  Google Developers
attachments.text: When you use FAQ structured data, you may help users discover information in a rich result. Learn about FAQ schema markup and see examples.
attachments.title: Mark Up FAQs with Structured Data | Google Search Central  |  Documentation  |  Google Developers

text:
I second Octavia. Teach them more about marketing, pull the veil back.

This has the added advantage of showing people how tough our work can be and reducing the feelings of intrusion.

elements.text:
I second Octavia. Teach them more about marketing, pull the veil back.

This has the added advantage of showing people how tough our work can be and reducing the feelings of intrusion.

text:
I do content optimization for clients and it's completely hands-off for them. They fill out an intake questionnaire which gives me all the info I need, and I get access to their Analytics, Search Console, etc.

From then on, I do all the necessary research to update optimize a set number of articles on a monthly basis. This includes checking what they're already ranking for, doing new keyword research if needed, doing competitor research, using Surfer to help with the optimization process, optimizing and adding new images if needed, updating the content, checking internal and external links, checking all the meta info, making sure all content is following a clear content plan, ... the works.

They have access to a continuously updated progress report where they can see which posts we're working on, as well as a monthly result report where we track traffic evolution for all of the pages we're working on.

I say "we" as I do all the research, strategy, and editing whereas my assistant does the optimization.

So from the client's side, there is no process they need to follow. Some of my clients do a double-check of the content to make sure what we did is on-brand, but because I have a solid intake process, that's usually not required.

Side note: I don't recommend letting them update in a Google doc as they'll only be updating the content. If you let them work in your CMS, they can update the meta info, the images, etc., and they can work with a tool such as Surfer to track keyword density.

I do content optimization for clients and it's completely hands-off for them. They fill out an intake questionnaire which gives me all the info I need, and I get access to their Analytics, Search Console, etc.

From then on, I do all the necessary research to update optimize a set number of articles on a monthly basis. This includes checking what they're already ranking for, doing new keyword research if needed, doing competitor research, using Surfer to help with the optimization process, optimizing and adding new images if needed, updating the content, checking internal and external links, checking all the meta info, making sure all content is following a clear content plan, ... the works.

They have access to a continuously updated progress report where they can see which posts we're working on, as well as a monthly result report where we track traffic evolution for all of the pages we're working on.

I say "we" as I do all the research, strategy, and editing whereas my assistant does the optimization.

So from the client's side, there is no process they need to follow. Some of my clients do a double-check of the content to make sure what we did is on-brand, but because I have a solid intake process, that's usually not required.

Side note: I don't recommend letting them update in a Google doc as they'll only be updating the content. If you let them work in your CMS, they can update the meta info, the images, etc., and they can work with a tool such as Surfer to track keyword density.

text:
First, I love this question as well as the project. If people aren’t marketers we have a tendency to be thought of the “arts and crafts” department within the org … others don’t see all the work that goes into what we do, just the “pretty” output. Use this as an opportunity to talk about how what you’re doing in marketing can/will effect the rest of the company — how are you working with sales? Engineering? Operations? Why does what you’re doing matter to people who aren’t in the marketing team?

And yeah, inject all kinds of personality into that ish … make it fun to read and consume!

Why does what you’re doing matter to people who aren’t in the marketing team?

And yeah, inject all kinds of personality into that ish … make it fun to read and consume!

text:
I don't see anything wrong with this approach.

But it's unlikely a Q&A article will move the needle much for SEO unless the questions themselves are commonly searched, so I'd just go with whatever formatting makes it the most readable.

text: All great advice here so far. One thing my old team did was show an end-to-end customer journey. If you're set up for multi-touch attribution it's something to consider!

text: A heads up: Formatting your text using headers for the appearance is fine - until you redesign. Then those readable h2s may be unwieldy.

elements.text: A heads up: Formatting your text using headers for the appearance is fine - until you redesign. Then those readable h2s may be unwieldy.
